At that time, the World-Honored One was surrounded by an innumerable great assembly and expounding the Dharma.

At that time, the elder's son Bianyi observed that the assembly was seated, and by receiving the Buddha's majestic spiritual power, he rose from his seat, adjusted his robes, and solemnly prostrated to the Buddha. He knelt for a long time with his palms joined, and addressed the Buddha, saying:
I wish to ask about something. I only pray that the World-Honored One will compassionately explain it.

The World-Honored One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the unsurpassed one in the three realms, with his spiritual transformations and the Way of the sages, delivers and guides all beings, universally expounding the expedient path, enabling the multitude to attain their proper places.

In the future world, the five turbidities will be in full boil, and the three poisons will be rampant, burning each other with this, without respect or humility, with poisonous thoughts towards each other. If the king covets the position of the country, raises troops to attack each other, and dies with a ruined reputation,

at that time, the calamities will extend to the common people. If the Buddha's disciples, the fourfold assembly, receive the Buddha's remaining grace and become known as practitioners of the Way, outwardly wearing the Dharma robes, inwardly harboring jealousy, without respect or obedience, slandering each other, promoting evil and suppressing good, being arrogant and not accepting others,

these people will all be destined for hell, hungry ghosts, and animals. For the glory of a moment, they do not know the calamities of future kalpas. With what Dharma should they be enlightened and transformed?

I only wish that the World-Honored One will fully demonstrate the teachings and transformations, so that people of the future may receive this blessing, escape the three evil paths, and forever dwell in the hall of blessings.

Excellent!

The Elder's son Bianyi has now made the lion's roar in front of the Buddha, giving rise to things and transforming everyone. The foolish, dark, and evil people of the future will receive this meaning, how delightful!
Do not hesitate to ask what you wish to ask. The TathÄgata will explain it for you.
The Elder's son Bianyi addressed the Buddha, saying:
For what reasons do people attain rebirth in the heavens?
For what reasons do they come to be reborn among humans?
For what reasons are they born in the hells?
For what reasons are they always born among hungry ghosts?
For what reasons are they born among animals?
For what reasons are they always born in noble families respected by the masses?
For what reasons are they born as slaves, serving others?
For what other causes and conditions are born among the common people, with fragrant breath, a peaceful mind and body, praised by others, and not slandered?
For what other causes and conditions does one attain birth as a human, always slandered, disliked by others, with an ugly appearance, an uneasy body and mind, always fearful?

For what other causes and conditions is one always united with the Buddha in one's place of birth, hears the Dharma and upholds it without initial error, encounters good friends and attains a good mind, and if one becomes a Å›ramaá¹‡a, always attains one's wishes?
Your questions are like this. I only wish that the World-Honored One would explain them in detail, so that this assembly may hear the correct teachings, and may all attain liberation and peace.
The Buddha told the elder's son Bianyi:ğŸ”½Listen carefully!
Listen carefully!
Think about it well!
I will explain the wonderful essentials for you.
There are five practices that lead to birth in the heavens.
What are the five?
First, with a compassionate mind, do not kill living beings but nurture all life, enabling all to attain peace;
Second, be virtuous and kind, do not steal others' possessions, give generously without greed, and help those in poverty;
Third, be chaste and pure, do not commit adultery, protect the precepts for men and women, and diligently uphold the fasts;
Fourth, be sincere and trustworthy, do not deceive others, protect the four verbal faults, and do not be greedy or deceitful;
Fifth, do not drink alcohol, and do not overindulge in food.
Through these five things, one can be reborn in the heavens.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
By not killing, one attains long life, is always healthy and well-fed,
And receives the status of a heavenly being, with a peaceful body and radiant appearance.
By not stealing, one is always greatly wealthy, with natural money and treasures,
With palaces made of the seven treasures, and entertainment that is always delightful.
By not engaging in sexual misconduct with men or women, one's body is fragrant and pure,
One will always be upright and handsome, with virtues and conduct naturally clear.
Not deceiving, one's breath will be fragrant, and one's speech will always be intelligent.
When discussing, one will not stutter, and what one says will be followed by the assembly.
Wine and meat will not pass one's lips, and one will have no confused or disordered thoughts.
If one is reborn in a place, devas and humans will always serve and attend.
If one's life ends, twenty-five spirits will welcome one.
Five blessings will naturally come, with light and radiance shining brightly.
The Buddha told Bianyi:
There are also five things that lead to rebirth among humans.
What are the five?
First, giving, with kindness and nourishment for the poor;
Second, upholding precepts, not committing the ten evil deeds;
Third, being patient, not disturbing the minds of the assembly;
Fourth, being diligent, encouraging and transforming the lazy;
Fifth, being single-minded, serving with filial piety and loyalty to the utmost.
These are the five things that lead to rebirth among humans, with great wealth, long life, upright appearance, majestic virtue, and becoming a human ruler, respected and served by all.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke in verse:
Through giving, one attains great wealth, with money and property naturally arising;
Wherever one is born, one is always noble, and immediately obtains the remaining wealth of one's father.
Upholding the precepts, always complete, following the teachings of the Three Jewels,
With utmost sincerity, not committing evil, one then attains a long lifespan.
Being patient and not disturbing the assembly, not giving rise to anger towards others,
Not retaliating when beaten or scolded, one is always upright in appearance wherever one is born.
Being diligent and not lazy, always thinking to uphold and practice,
Wherever one is born, one is immediately powerful, becoming the leader of all.
Being single-minded and not turning back, with loyal thoughts and sincerity,
Serving and attending to the elders, wherever one is born, there are no difficulties.
If one practices these five things, one will be reborn as a human ruler,
With wealth, power, and a handsome appearance, naturally becoming a valiant general.
The Buddha further told Bianyi:
There are five practices that lead to rebirth in hell for billions of eons.
What are the five?
First, not believing in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha, slandering and disparaging the noble path;
Second, destroying Buddhist temples and shrines;
Third, the four groups slandering and disparaging each other, not believing in the consequences of karma and lacking respectful intentions;
Fourth, being rebellious and lacking respect for superiors and inferiors, with rulers, ministers, fathers, and sons not following each other;
Fifth, those who wish to enter the path in the future, having already entered the path, not following the teacher's teachings but being self-important and slandering the teacher with contempt.
These are the five practices that lead to rebirth in hell, transmigrating through hells without any hope of escape.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
The foolish people in the world do not believe in the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saá¹ƒgha,
With foolish thoughts they wish to destroy and slander the Buddha, saying he has no spiritual powers.
With their own eyes they see good and evil, and therefore commit various offenses,
Destroying shrines, with little benefit but great offenses.
In the latter age, the four groups harbor poison and jealousy,
Slandering each other for the sake of fame and profit, not knowing the grave consequences that follow.
The various ministers in the world, fathers and sons, harm each other,
For the sake of wealth, profit, and fame, they have no respectful or obedient thoughts.
In the future, evil people will become monks,
Not accepting their teachers' teachings, they will suffer grave consequences after death.
Those who engage in these five actions have offenses that cannot be described,
For eons in hell, even the Buddhas cannot save them.
Furthermore, son of a wealthy family!
There are five things that lead to rebirth as a hungry ghost.
What are the five?
First, being stingy and greedy, not wanting to give in charity;
Second, stealing, not being filial to one's parents;
Third, being ignorant and lacking a compassionate heart;
Fourth, hoarding wealth and not willing to spend it on clothing and food;
Fifth, not providing for one's parents, siblings, wife, children, and servants.
These five things lead to rebirth as a hungry ghost.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke in verse:
Being stingy and not giving in charity, privately stealing and not supporting one's relatives,
Hoarding wealth for fear of losing it, lacking compassion for the elderly,
Not providing for one's wife, children, and servants,
Sitting and guarding one's wealth until death, the suffering of hungry ghosts is great.
The body does not see clothing, the belly is large, and the throat is like a needle.
Going east and west in search of food, molten copper is poured into the mouth,
Not wanting to drink it, he slapped his mouth and forced him to swallow it.
One mouthful entered his stomach, and his liver, lungs, intestines, and stomach rotted.
Such hardship, he went through for tens of thousands of years,
When his crimes were exhausted, he was able to escape and was born as a poor and lowly person.
Furthermore, son of a wealthy family!
There are also five things that lead to rebirth as an animal.
What are the five?
First, violating precepts and secretly stealing;
Second, owing debts and refusing to repay;
Third, killing to repay debts;
Fourth, not delighting in listening to and receiving the Dharma;
Fifth, always using difficult circumstances, fasts, and charity events as worldly reasons.
These five things lead to rebirth as an animal.
Then, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Always secretly stealing others' things, owing money and refusing to repay,
Taking pleasure in killing, hunting, and fishing, engaging in worldly affairs and unlawful gatherings,
Lacking sincerity and faith, not knowing the way, past, future, and present events.
Committing various offenses without awareness, gradually accumulating and falling into the animal realm,
Cattle, horses, elephants, donkeys, camels, pigs, sheep, dogs, countless,
Always bearing heavy burdens and dying, their skin flayed off, such suffering is extremely difficult to bear.
Furthermore, son of a wealthy family!
There are also five things that can lead to a noble status respected by the masses.
What are the five?
First, being generous and giving widely;
Second, paying respect to the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, as well as the elders;
Third, being patient and free from anger;
Fourth, being gentle and humble;
Fifth, extensively studying and reciting the scriptures and precepts.
These five things can lead to a noble status respected by the masses.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke in verse:
Always giving with an equal mind, universally saving and making the multitude peaceful,
With complexion, strength, longevity, and no illness, relatives and close ones all receive grace.
Those who respect the Buddha, the Three Jewels, and make offerings to the venerable elders,
Will be born as noble and always receive the respect of all.
Forbearing with patience and without anger, one will be born with proper appearance,
And the multitude will rejoice upon seeing them, gazing without being satisfied.
With a disciplined mind, able to be gentle and yielding, humble and respectful,
Studying and reciting the scriptures, one will become the most honored among people.
Furthermore, son of a wealthy family!
There are also five things that always lead to being born lowly as a slave.
What are the five?
First, being arrogant and disrespectful to one's parents;
Second, being obstinate and lacking a reverent mind;
Third, being negligent and not respecting the Three Jewels;
Fourth, stealing as a means of livelihood;
Fifth, running away from debts without repaying them.
These five things always lead to being born in a lowly slave's womb.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke in verse, saying:
If there are foolish people who are arrogant towards their parents,
Without a respectful mind, they will later be born lowly and humble.
Not paying homage to the Three Jewels, being obstinate towards elders,
Without kindness and filial piety towards others, they will be born as slaves.
Letting their minds run wild, they steal other people's belongings,
Running away from debts without wanting to repay them, they will later be born as slaves.
Relying on others for clothing and food, running errands without independence,
Working hard to repay their masters, they may escape once their crimes are finished.
Furthermore, son of a wealthy family!
There are also five things that lead to being born among humans, with a fragrant mouth, a peaceful mind and body, being praised by others and not slandered.
What are the five?
First, being sincere and not deceiving others;
Second, reciting the sutras without discrimination;
Third, guarding the mouth and not slandering the holy path;
Fourth, teaching people to distance themselves from evil and approach goodness;
Fifth, not seeking the faults of others.
These five things lead to rebirth among humans, with fragrant breath, a peaceful body and mind, praise from others, and no slander.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Respecting the Three Jewels, not being arrogant towards parents,
Being sincere and not deceitful, this is the practice respected by people.
Guarding the mouth and not slandering, having an impartial mind towards all,
Encouraging people to distance themselves from wrongdoing, reciting and practicing the true Dharma.
People in the world are not arrogant, respecting each other like parents,
Suppressing evil and promoting goodness, thus attaining Buddhahood quickly.
Furthermore, son of a wealthy family!
There are also five things. If one is among humans, one will always be slandered, disliked by others, have an ugly body, an uneasy mind, and always harbor fear.
What are the five?
First, always lacking sincerity and deceiving others;
Second, at Dharma-speaking assemblies, slandering them;
Third, seeing fellow students, slighting and testing them;
Fourth, not seeing others' affairs, creating faults for them;
Fifth, divisive speech, causing disputes between them.
These are the five things. If one is among humans, one will always be slandered, disliked by others, have an ugly body, an uneasy mind, and always harbor fear.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Deceiving and confusing the masses, always lacking sincerity,
With mind and mouth creating actions, causing the body to receive heavy punishment.
If reborn in hell, iron hooks will pull out their tongues,
And molten copper will be poured into their mouths, day and night without rest.
If they are to be reborn as humans, their breath will always smell foul,
And people will not be pleased upon seeing them, without any joy or delight.
They will always encounter legal matters, and be criticized by others,
Encountering many calamities and difficulties, their minds will never be at ease,
Dying, they will return to hell, and upon release will become animals,
Transmigrating through the five paths, they will not escape the many sufferings and difficulties.
Furthermore, son of a wealthy family!

There are also five things, wherever they are born, they will always be with the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, never deviating, seeing the Buddha and hearing the Dharma will bring forth a good mind, if they become monks they will attain their wishes.
What are the five?
First, with one's body serving the Three Jewels, encouraging others to serve them;
Second, when making Buddha images, they should be made fresh and clean;
Third, always follow the teacher's teachings and do not violate the precepts;
Fourth, universally have compassion for all, treating them equally as one's own body, like loving one's own child;
Fifth, recite the sutras and Dharma day and night.

These are the five things. Wherever one is born, one will always be with the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, never deviating. Seeing the Buddha and hearing the Dharma, one will attain a good mind. If one becomes a monk, one will attain one's wishes.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Respecting the Three Jewels, teaching and encouraging others to serve them,
Making beautiful Buddha images, following the teachings of the honored teachers.
One should view all people, treating them equally as one's own body,
With self and others equally, practicing this one will gather before the Buddha.
Day and night always studying, wisdom is a great treasure,
Enlightening the blind and confused, universally causing them to know the true path.

Then, the elder's son Bianyi, hearing the Buddha explain the meaning of the fifty essential dharmas, was delighted and joyfully attained acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas. Five hundred elder's sons all attained the purity of the Dharma eye, and the assembly each attained their aspirations.
Then, Bianyi immediately rose from his seat, bowed to the Buddha, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and said to the Buddha:
Excellent!
World-Honored One!
You have eloquently explained this Dharma, causing those in the assembly to hear what they have not heard before, and will enable future generations to be saved from difficulties.
I only wish that the World-Honored One would pass through the poor village and the various assemblies, and have a meal at my house tomorrow at noon.
At that time, the World-Honored One silently accepted.
The elder's sons bowed to the Buddha and joyfully departed.
Bianyi returned home and said to his parents:
The one I am requesting is difficult to find among humans. He is called the TathÄgata, the unsurpassed Dharma teacher, without compare in the three realms.
He then told his wife to prepare food and drink, and they immediately set out the feast.
The next day, the World-Honored One, together with the great assembly, went to their house and sat down in order.
At that time, the parents and relatives of the elder's son, Bianyi, bowed at the Buddha's feet and each served him.
Bianyi rose to wash the water and respectfully offered the food.

Before the food was finished, a beggar came and went around the seats begging. Since the Buddha had not yet given the blessing, no one dared to give him anything. He went around everywhere without getting anything, became angry and left, and then gave rise to evil thoughts:
These Å›ramaá¹‡as are indulgent and foolish. What path do they have?
When I beg from the poor, they have no intention of giving.
The elder is deluded and uses it to feed these uncompassionate ones.
If I become the king, I will use an iron-rimmed chariot to crush his head!
Having said this, he left.

After the Buddha had finished the ritual of giving, a beggar came in to beg. The people in the assembly each gave him food, and he obtained a lot of food. He was delighted and left, thinking to himself:
These Å›ramaá¹‡as all have compassionate hearts. They pity my poverty and cold, giving me food to fill my belly, which will sustain me for several days.
Excellent!
The elder is able to serve these great beings, and his blessings will be immeasurable.
If I become king, I will make offerings to the Buddha and his disciples for seven days, repaying today's kindness of relieving my hunger and thirst.
Having said this, he left.
After the Buddha had finished his meal and spoken the Dharma, he returned to the monastery.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
From now on, after the ritual of giving, we will eat this as usual.
At that time, the two beggars wandered begging and arrived in another country, lying in the deep grass by the roadside.
At that time, the king of that country suddenly passed away, and there was no heir.
The national physiognomist, who was well-versed in physiognomy and prophecy, recorded in a prophecy:
There will be a lowly person who should become the king.
The ministers, officials, thousands of carriages, and thousands of horsemen inspected the country, wondering who should be the king.
They saw a canopy of clouds above the deep grass by the side of the road.
The physiognomist pointed and said:
There is a divine person within!
They saw a beggar who was suitable to be the king.
The ministers bowed and addressed him as their lord.
The beggar was startled and said he was lowly and not of royal blood.
They all said he had the proper marks, not that he was powerful.
He bathed in fragrant water, put on the king's robes, his radiance was majestic, and he was praised immeasurably. He led his followers, turned his carriage, and entered the country.
At that time, the one with evil thoughts was lying asleep in the deep grass, and his head was crushed by the carriage.
The king arrived in the country, and the yin and yang were in harmony, with the four qi flourishing, and the people were at peace and happy, praising the king's virtue.
At that time, the king thought to himself:
By what causes and conditions did I, a poor person, become the king of a country?
When I was begging for alms in the past, I received the Buddha's grace and obtained a lot of food and drink. I then had a good thought:
'If I become a king, I will make offerings for seven days.
' The Buddha's gracious virtue has now been fulfilled.
He then summoned his ministers and bowed in the direction of the country of Shravasti, burning incense.
He then sent a messenger to invite the Buddha, saying:
I have received the World-Honored One's gracious gift and become the king of men.
I wish that you would deign to come and transform this ignorant country, so that we may see your teachings.
Thereupon, the Buddha told his disciples:
You should accept his invitation.
The Buddha, together with countless disciples, went to that country.
The king came out to greet him, and together with his ministers he bowed at the Buddha's feet, burned incense, scattered flowers, and made offerings with music.
When the Buddha entered the palace, he took his seat. The king served water and set out food and drink, which were finished in an instant.
At that time, the king of the country bowed to the Buddha and said to him:
I was originally a small person. What meritorious deeds did I have to enjoy this position?
I wish the Buddha would explain it, so that the people of this country may be enlightened.
The Buddha told the king:
In the past, in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ«, there was the son of an elder named Bianyi, who held a great almsgiving and invited the Buddha and the Sangha.
At that time, when the Buddha was seated, before the food was offered, there was a beggar who came in to beg but got nothing. He left in anger, giving rise to evil thoughts, saying:
'If I were the king, I would use an iron-rimmed chariot to crush the heads of the monks!
One person came later and begged for food, receiving a great deal. As he left, he thought:
If I were the king, I would make offerings to this assembly of sages for seven days.
The one with good thoughts is now the king;

The one with evil thoughts was lying in the deep grass. When the king received the position of king, he turned his chariot and entered the country. The chariot and cavalry attendants crushed his head, and he died and entered hell, being crushed by a fiery chariot for millions of eons before being released.
The king now invites the Buddha, repaying his vow with great thickness, receiving blessings for generation after generation, with no end in sight.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
The human mind is the root of poison, and the mouth is the door of calamity.
If one thinks with the mind and speaks with the mouth, one will receive the suffering of punishment with the body.
One who does not think of good or evil people creates suffering for themselves.
If one wishes to harm others, one will not notice the chariot crushing their head.
The mind is the sweet dew of the Dharma, causing people to be born in the heavens,
Thinking in the mind and speaking with the mouth, the body receives its blessings and virtues.
Those who think of good and evil, create their own foundation for peace,
Thinking of all good in the mind, like a king obtaining the position of heaven.
At that time, the king of the country joyfully heard the sutra and the entire country's ministers and people attained the path of stream-entry.

After making offerings to the Buddha for seven days, the Buddha was about to leave. The king and his ministers bowed to the Buddha and took their leave. Then the World-Honored One returned to the Jeta Grove in Shravasti.
The Venerable Ananda adjusted his robes, rose from his seat, bowed to the Buddha, knelt for a long time, and said to the Buddha:
What should this sutra be called, and how should it be upheld?
The Buddha told Ananda:
This sutra is called 'The Questions of the Elder's Son Bianyi.' It should be upheld. It is also called 'The Essential Meaning of All Dharmas.'
